Using the aeropress standard filter cap, the water begins to flow through the filter immediately, and although placing the plunger on top stops the flow, it’s an unknown variable of water quantity that flows through the filter before stopping the flow with the plunger. This improved filter cap keeps the entire amount of water mixed with the grounds until the specified time, before using the plunger. And it easier and safer than inverting the aeropress.

One issue, when you tap out the used filter, be sure the rubber round gasket doesn’t pop out in the trash or sink. It won’t work without it.

I highly recommend this product. I would like Aeropress to sell a slightly more expensive aeropress option with this filter cap, because this filter cap is a bit pricey, and the stock filter cap is no longer needed. But until that ever happens, this is a required purchase.

title: No need to invert anymore, makes Espresso-like coffee and foam.
body:
This review is specifically for the Aeropress flow control Filter cap.

The biggest caveat is that this does not come with a metal filter like the Fellow Prismo does. Had I known that, I might have considered the third party product instead, given how competitive the prices are for what you get. However, I have heard of third party metal filters warping the aeropress in order to use it properly. I assume you get the peace of mind that this will not warp your product, by itself of when used with Aerobie's own metal filter.

Build quality feels reasonable, although it can flex if you squeeze it right. It has a nice grippy texture along the edge that makes it easy to unscrew, and plenty of surface area to grip it for installing and removing it. Compared to the filter cap that comes with the Aeropress, it's much easier to install and remove. I don't have any trouble gripping it even when the cap is wet, although it is much taller and wont fit inside the Aeropress Go's case.

I tested it with an off-the-shelf dark roast coffee, finely ground in my cheapo 40 dollar cuisinart grinder, and just enough 200 degree water to make the grounds stir-able, steeped for one minute and pressed with reasonable effort. It produced a nice concentrated espresso-like drink with a significantly larger layer of foam compared to similar efforts with the stock cap. The flavor seemed different too, and in a way that I liked. I understand the aeropress and similar manuals cannot produce a true espresso, but it can make a nice substitute in my opinion.

Ive been brewing with this cap regularly in my Aeropress go, sometimes for espresso-like concentrates, but often larger servings as well. I typically prefer the "inverted method" (even though it doesn't affect the coffee, its just the process I like), but this cap generally stops water from leaking out early. I can use the Aeropress as intended (reducing spills, water burns, or wasted coffee), and squeeze more water into the chamber since I'm not worrying about keeping the plunger well-seated for a flip.

UPDATE: Had some leaking issues with the cap and figured it was just user error or something. I recently found out Aerobie revised the design with a rubber gasket over this issue, and they sent me the revised model at no charge when I told them I was having leaking issues. It's still not perfect, though the revised version works MUCH better. Having used the flow control cap for a year and Aeropress coffeemakers for much longer, this is easily the best accessory for the product. I just wish the price was competitive with the Fellow Prismo kit.

body:
I've been an Aeropress fan well over 7 years and love the product. I take it traveling and very happy with it's performance and durability. I've met Alan Adler at tradeshows and he's a superstar along with his team.

The good news is, the Flow Control Cap performs the same or better than the standard cap with many brew holes. Yes, it's great that the new cap prevents initial drops getting into the brew early. It's easy to operate, and unless I actually knew I was using the 'new' cap...I wouldn't have known the difference during brewing. So, very happy with the final coffee product it makes.

The not so good new is, I think Aeropress fell short on this new brewing cap. And, for those who know about this trick, on the Prismo video, they suggest pulling the cylinder back to get the filter off the cap...but it didn't work for me.

Again, I love the Aeropress in an of itself and will continue to use it, but with the old cap. I hope the R&D folks can figure out how to stop the leaking and make the filter release from the cap for ejection.

title: Best way (currently) to use metal filter screen
body:
This incorporates a ketchup bottle squeeze valve which only allows liquid to pass through when you press on it, thereby permitting water to remain in the cylinder until you're ready. When I tried a metal filter with the normal cap, water would pour straight through it without so much as a by-your-leave, resulting in a brown but flavorless liquid (with fine silt at the bottom of my cup). The flow control valve allows me to brew actual coffee (with fine silt at the bottom).

That's the positive, now the not-so-positive and negative:

The valve has four little posts around it. Before your first use I would recommend pressing on these to make sure they are level with the little risers inside the cap. Mine was a little higher when it arrived, and put a tiny dent in my metal filter. Before the second use, I pressed on it with my finger and it went "click" and is now level.

The squirt valve works great when liquid is passing through it, but once you get to the air pocket it sputters and sprays. This is what causes the "coffee running down the sides of the mug" problem that some reviewers experienced. I checked very carefully and verified that the cap is NOT leaking around the seal, and coffee is only escaping through the valve. That running-down-the-sides coffee is getting splashed up from INSIDE THE MUG by bursts of air from the valve. I recommend that you STOP pressing when you get to the air bubble, lift the Aeropress off of your mug, and push the piston down the rest of the way over the sink.

This cap is about 6mm thicker/taller than the original cap. That extra thickness goes down into your cup and leaves that much less room for coffee. Great if you plan to put cream in it, disappointing if you drink it black.

Even after pressing all the way down, this cap leaves my coffee grounds significantly wetter than the original cap does. That's a few drops of liquid that didn't go into my cup (what a tragedy) and a slightly messier cleanup.

Speaking of cleanup, there is a rubber gasket ring that you probably should knock out of there (assuming it doesn't fall out on its own, watch out for that) to give the whole assembly a proper rinse after each use.

All in all, this gadget gets the job done (when the job is holding water in the cylinder long enough to allow actual coffee to form) but I can't understand why Aeropress didn't go the simple and obvious route: To reduce flow rate, just make a filter with FEWER HOLES. Am I crazy? Is there a reason why that wouldn't work?? One star removed for being more fiddly than it needed to be.

title: Works, but only after modification
body:

The flanges on the edges that fit into the bottom of the carafe were too thick - when you turned the cap to affix it to the carafe, it wouldn't turn all the way. This leaves gaps, and allows for leakage when you press the plunger. You wouldn't notice the poor fit if you didn't turn the carafe upside down and look at it. (Please refer to photos. First shows flange not fully inserted. Second shows it fully inserted.) That's when I saw that, though I had turned the cap as far as it would go, there was still ¼ inch left of the channel that the flanges fit into. I had to take a metal file and file down the flanges until they fully fit into the carafe. The insertion of filters, metal and/or paper, make a big difference, too. I got the cap to fit, then put in filters and it didn't fit any more. So I had to file it some more. It works now, though there is still leakage when you get down to the air pocket between grounds and plunger.
Another difficulty with this product is that the paper filters don't want to come out of the cap. The irregular surface on the inside of the cap just grabs the paper filter and doesn't want to let go. I have fixed this problem by inserting a metal filter first, then a paper filter on top of that. Why use the paper at all? It's easier to separate the metal filter from the paper one and make sure it doesn't get thrown away. This dual filter definitely made a difference in getting the cap to fit the carafe.
All in all, the product does control the flow of coffee, so it doesn't all leak through before you press the plunger. But the path to getting it to work as it should was much more difficult than it should have been. I hope this has been helpful.

title: Improvement over the Aeropress Original Screw Cap
body: My Original Aeropress had two areas that needed correction, and the two after-market items—available from Amazon—that did the correcting were (1) the AeroPress Flow Control Filter Cap along with (2) an Altura stainless steel DIsc filter. Paper filters are for me undesirable because they reduce the mouthfeel and flavor of the brew by trapping coffee oils. And the original Aeropress twist cap lets the brew leak out immediately, making it impossible to choose the immersion time. Control of your immersion time therefore necessitates using the inverted method, which thereby reduces the usable interior volume so that in order to make a normal sized cup of coffee you need to then add more hot water after pressing out your brew. The Aeropress Flow Control FIlter Cap is not absolutely drip-free but it is close enough. The slight increase in required pressure helps to extract a bit more of the good stuff inside those ground coffee beans. So although it's kinda expensive, it is an improvement over the original screw cap. I also have the new Aeropress XL and it has the same two defects of the Original, and it therefore also needs both a proper-sized Flow Control Filter Cap and a larger Altura Disc Filter. Then it will be as good as it can be.

I find if I wet the paper filter before putting the cap on, it's easier to get on tight enough.)

As far as taste goes, I had mixed results. I brewed two times using different roasts. My first cup was a dark roast. I like it about the same as without the valve. My second cup was a blonde roast. That cup was much better with the valve than without. I was surprised how much more I liked it. I never used the inverted method so I can''t compare it to that but I'm sure results would be similar.

I can't compare it directly with the Prismo as I've never tried it. But, from what I understand,the Prismo can't be used with only a paper filter. That is probably the only advantage to the Aeropress filter cap. So, if you don't care about a metal filter, buy the Aeropress and save five bucks. title: 2 AEROPRESS CHAMBERS CRACKED.
body:
Hello everyone! This is my review for the new Aeropress Filter flow control cap:

DO NOT BUY IT. ESPECIALLY IF YOU LOVE YOUR AEROPRESS. ITS A WASTE OF MONEY. IT BROKE TWO CHAMBERS.

This cap does wonders, it allows you to bypass the “inverted method” so you don’t have to flip anything or risk burning yourself and making a mess. This product seemed like an easy buy to fix the drip issue with the OG cap that it comes with, I thought it would have been great. And it was, I loved using the product and it does what it does as advertised. I love that you can use paper filters or the metal one, it’s very versatile.

But save your money and just use the inverted method. I have an Aeropress Go. The first couple of times I put the new cap on the Go, it got unbelievably stuck. I nearly broke my wrist trying to unscrew it every morning. Eventually, it got easier to screw on and off, but with a catch. I noticed there was a giant crack line on the aeropress chamber. I was devastated. (Pictures 1 and 2 are the old chamber with the crack)

I contacted aeropress support about it and they happily explained that the cap should be tight, but not tight enough where it’s almost impossible to screw off. They happily sent me a new Go chamber to replace the cracked one. I got it yesterday and was so excited to try the cap again with this new one! I thought since it was new it’d probably be easier to screw on and off and should work better.

Boy, was I wrong. This morning sucked. The cap got super stuck AGAIN on the brand new chamber, and when I finally unscrewed it, you guessed it. Another new crack line discovered, on a brand new chamber. I know it’s not the chambers fault that it broke - I immediately switched to just the given cap and that works perfect. But I am so mad that this flow cap just broke a new chamber. A NEW ONE. (Picture 3 is the new chamber with the crack)

Therefore, this thing is a waste of money. Don’t buy it, it will break your Aeropress. It literally did it twice. Save your money and don’t break the chamber, just to stop the drip through. I can’t say that if I had a regular aeropress, it’d do the same thing, but regardless I can’t believe this happened twice.

Aeropress, thanks for being a great company, and your service team helped me a lot. But fix your product, it’s terrible.

title: Mixed feelings
body:
By way of background: I've been using an Aeropress for more than a decade. I own 3 (for different locations) and all three are different generations and I love them all equally. I've gifted over a dozen to my favorite people over the years. I love this invention.

This little innovation though, clearly on the heels of what the folks over at Fellows did with the Prismo and a step in 'that' direction but is it the 'right' direction? I am not convinced, especially given how revolutionary the original Aeropress was. Btw, the Aeropress valve cap appears to be a different design than the Prismo.

What I like:
- no premature drips when using the standard method, and therefore no need to use the inverted method.
- well constructed and appears to be universally compatible w/ all generations of the Aeropress.

What I dislike (in order of gripy'ness):
- paper filter stays glued to the cap and gets messy trying to get it off, compared to the reliable process on the original cap, where the used paper is exposed as soon as you take the cap off, and you can choose to discard it by plunging it into the trash along w/ the puck OR remove and wash it, and reuse it.
- have to push harder (depending on the fineness of your grind) on the plunger due to the valve - which might yield bitterness in the cup.

After a few weeks of ownership, I find that light/medium roasts do really well w/ the valve cap but the net result is definitely not espresso. Medium/dark roasts are better (smoother, specifically) w/ the original cap compared to the valve cap. I find the valve cap begins to introduce some bitterness that deviates from the smoothness that the Aeropress is known for. Also, the bitterness is managed when you use cream/sugar but prevalent if drinking straight up.. so it may not bother you if you typically take your coffee w/ cream and/or sugar.

title: Evolution, not revolution
body:
AeroPress makes great stuff - I’ve had my original press for over a decade, picked up a second one for the office, have bought them as gifts for friends and family, and, in a testament to how well thought-out their design process is, am on my second set of seals after the first started to wear out. Suffice it to say, I was thrilled at the prospect of a flow control cap that would let me generate more pressure and avoid mid-brew drips. I’ve become a fan of moka pot-brewed coffee, so I was curious to see if I could coax more intensity from my AeroPress-brewed presses.

The cap itself is of the quality I’ve come to expect from everything AeroPress does - solid, precisely engineered, and of obvious quality. Instead of the familiar matrix of round holes, this new cap has a single hole with a cross-cut membrane in it (think of modern condiment squeeze bottle caps), with a pattern of raised ridges inside the cap to guide the coffee through its new exit. The cap seats tightly on the cylinder when you twist it into place.

Following the recommendations included in the box and on the AeroPress website, I went for a preliminary stir (per normal brewing), followed by an extended steep (impossible in normal brewing, thanks to gradual leakage through the standard cap).

First, and most importantly, the coffee was delicious. That smooth, no-bitterness coffee that AeroPress excels at producing. Thanks to the new no-drip cap and the longer brew time, the flavor was deeper and stronger than I could get with my original cap. The extra pressure also allows for crema - it matches the bloom from when you first add hot water beautifully. It’s still not espresso (or moka) strength, but it is a step up from the basic configuration if you like your coffee strong.

Performance-wise, I would call this more of an improvement over a standard AeroPress than a true no-drip cap. You’re not going to suddenly start getting espressos. As you can see in the picture (I made a latte for the contrast with the milk), there are some drips, but they are minor compared to a standard cap. So still not as effective for longer brew time as adding water and inverting the unit, using the plunger as a stopper, but much easier and equally delicious.

Note that this only replaces the standard filter cap on the AeroPress Coffee Maker with a cap that has a resistive, one-way valve on it. The Aeropress system itself needs to be purchased separately.
This accessory does messily spit out good, strong coffee with a bit of something that looks like an espresso crema; though it doesn't produce much of it, and it disappears quickly, since it is only a little foamy.
The AeroPress coffee maker always does make good coffee; and with this accessory, it gets a little closer to producing an espresso.
But, still, not quite the real thing.

title: Works fine on AeroPress Go Portable Travel Kit
body: Initially this is a bit of a struggle to get attached, especially compared to the OEM version, but don't worry it will fit. It's snug for a reason - so it won't leak and will withstand the increased pressure it was designed for, to produce a better almost espresso like cup of coffee. To say the AeroPress can make espresso is nonsense. It wasn't designed for that purpose and cannot withstand the pressures required to make good espresso, but it does make an excellent cup of joe in my opinion. The most important thing is size of grind, and you're just going to have to experiment until you find the one you like best. Start with drip grind size and work your way down from there until you find the sweet spot. For those who are new to AeroPress world, never, ever put your AeroPress in the dishwasher...and never, ever leave the silicone plunger seal compressed inside the tube for more than the time it takes to make a cup of coffee. Once rinsed and dried, push the plunger all the way through until the silicone plunger cap pops out the end of the cylinder (per photo). Note, the new flow control filter cap is taller than the OEM version and as such will not allow the cap to fit if you place the filter wallet on top of it. No big deal for me, but something you should be aware of. Overall, I really like this and after a little getting used to, I'm making better coffee in the AeroPress than before. Although my go to coffee maker at home these days is a Breville Nespresso Vertuo, that puts a world class crema on top of each shot, but I digress. This is certainly worth the small investment and something I would recommend to every AeroPress aficionado. Afterall, you didn't wind up with one of these machines because you don't care about flavor. You obviously do, and this will give you one more option to up your game. Just be prepared for a little fussing around to get it dialed in...and to get that dang thing tightly attached. Don't give up, it will be worth your time. Prepare for one disaster and if it doesn't happen, all the better. Cheers!

And I never tried the inverted method because it sounded like too much planning, hassle, and potential for a mess. However, with the Flow Control Filter Cap, zero water gets through until you plunge, so the grinds get super saturated, and the result is a rich cup of cold brew in just one minute. This is truly nearly as good as Toddy cold brew, albeit with far less time, effort, and counter space. You can also now use pre-ground coffee — which has a slightly coarser-than-recommended grind — without the water quickly draining into your cup. The Flow Control Filter Cap unlocks the full potential and versatility of the Aeropress to the point that I now use it more than my Cuisinart coffee maker, and I look forward to traveling with it so I no longer have to search for good coffee while on the road.
